an3.36:1.1.eng: “There are, mendicants, these three messengers of the gods.

an3.36:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.36:1.3.eng: Firstly, someone does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.36:1.4.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an3.36:1.4.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an3.36:1.5.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā nānābāhāsu gahetvā yamassa rañño dassenti:
an3.36:1.5.eng: The wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying:

an3.36:1.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ, deva, puriso amatteyyo apetteyyo asāmañño abrahmañño, na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyī.
an3.36:1.6.eng: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.

an3.36:2.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
an3.36:2.1.eng: Then King Yama pursues, presses, and grills them about the first messenger of the gods:

an3.36:2.2.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
an3.36:2.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

an3.36:3.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā āsītikaṃ vā nāvutikaṃ vā vassasatikaṃ vā jātiyā jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyaṇaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantaṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ khaṇḍadantaṃ palitakesaṃ vilūnaṃ khallitasiraṃ valitaṃ tilakāhatagattan’ti?
an3.36:3.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings an elderly woman or a man—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy?’

an3.36:4.2.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
an3.36:4.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

an3.36:4.3.pli: ahampi khomhi jarādhammo jaraṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi, kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
an3.36:4.3.eng: “I, too, am liable to grow old. I’m not exempt from old age. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

an3.36:5.2.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
an3.36:5.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.36:5.3.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
an3.36:5.3.eng: Indeed, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

an3.36:5.4.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
an3.36:5.4.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

an3.36:5.5.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
an3.36:5.5.eng: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

an3.36:6.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā, dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
an3.36:6.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the second messenger of the gods:

an3.36:6.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
an3.36:6.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the second messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

an3.36:6.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ābādhikaṃ dukkhitaṃ bāḷhagilānaṃ, sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānaṃ, aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṃ, aññehi saṃvesiyamānan’ti?
an3.36:6.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others?’

an3.36:7.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi:
an3.36:7.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

an3.36:7.3.pli: “ahampi khomhi byādhidhammo byādhiṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā”’ti?
an3.36:7.3.eng: “I, too, am liable to become sick. I’m not exempt from sickness. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

an3.36:8.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
an3.36:8.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.36:8.3.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
an3.36:8.3.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

an3.36:8.4.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
an3.36:8.4.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

an3.36:8.5.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ. Tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
an3.36:8.5.eng: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

an3.36:9.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā, tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
an3.36:9.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the third messenger of the gods:

an3.36:9.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
an3.36:9.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the third messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

an3.36:10.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātan’ti?
an3.36:10.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering?’

an3.36:11.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
an3.36:11.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

an3.36:11.3.pli: ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo maraṇaṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
an3.36:11.3.eng: “I, too, am liable to die. I’m not exempt from death. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

an3.36:12.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
an3.36:12.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.36:12.3.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
an3.36:12.3.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

an3.36:12.4.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
an3.36:12.4.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

an3.36:12.5.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ. Tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’”ti.
an3.36:12.5.eng: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

an3.36:13.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā tuṇhī hoti.
an3.36:13.1.eng: After grilling them about the third messenger of the gods, King Yama falls silent.

an3.36:13.2.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā pañcavidhabandhanaṃ nāma kāraṇaṃ karonti.
an3.36:13.2.eng: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.

an3.36:13.3.pli: Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ hatthe gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiyasmiṃ hatthe gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ pāde gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiyasmiṃ pāde gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ majjhe urasmiṃ gamenti.
an3.36:13.3.eng: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.

an3.36:13.4.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
an3.36:13.4.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

an3.36:14.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā saṃvesetvā kudhārīhi tacchanti.
an3.36:14.1.eng: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

an3.36:14.2.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.

an3.36:15.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā vāsīhi tacchanti …pe…
an3.36:15.1.eng: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …

an3.36:15.2.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā rathe yojetvā ādittāya bhūmiyā sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya sārentipi paccāsārentipi …pe…
an3.36:15.2.eng: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …

an3.36:15.3.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi …pe…
an3.36:15.3.eng: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

an3.36:15.4.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā tattāya lohakumbhiyā pakkhipanti, ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya. (…)
an3.36:15.4.eng: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.

an3.36:15.5.pli: So tattha pheṇuddehakaṃ paccamāno sakimpi uddhaṃ gacchati, sakimpi adho gacchati, sakimpi tiriyaṃ gacchati.
an3.36:15.5.eng: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.

an3.36:15.6.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
an3.36:15.6.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

an3.36:15.7.eng: The wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell.

an3.36:16.1.eng: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,

an3.36:17.1.eng: The ground is even made of iron,

an3.36:18.1.eng: Once upon a time, King Yama thought,

an3.36:18.2.pli: ‘ye kira, bho, loke pāpakāni kammāni karonti te evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā karīyanti.
an3.36:18.2.eng: ‘Those who do such bad deeds in the world receive these many different punishments.

an3.36:18.3.pli: Aho vatāhaṃ manussattaṃ labheyyaṃ, tathāgato ca loke uppajjeyya arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, tañcāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāseyyaṃ.
an3.36:18.3.eng: Oh, I hope I may be reborn as a human being! And that a Realized One—a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—arises in the world! And that I may pay homage to the Buddha!

an3.36:18.4.pli: So ca me bhagavā dhammaṃ deseyya, tassa cāhaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ ājāneyyan’ti.
an3.36:18.4.eng: Then the Buddha can teach me Dhamma, so that I may understand his teaching.’

an3.36:18.5.pli: Taṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā evaṃ vadāmi, api ca kho, bhikkhave, yadeva me sāmaṃ ñātaṃ sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sāmaṃ viditaṃ tadevāhaṃ vadāmīti.
an3.36:18.5.eng: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.

an3.36:19.1.eng: When warned by the gods’ messengers,

an3.36:19.2.eng: those sons of Manu who are negligent

an3.36:19.4.eng: when they go to that wretched place.

an3.36:20.1.eng: When warned by the gods’ messengers,

an3.36:20.2.eng: the good and true persons here,

an3.36:20.4.eng: the teaching of the Noble One.

an3.36:21.2.eng: the origin of birth and death,

an3.36:21.4.eng: with the ending of birth and death.

an3.36:22.1.eng: Happy, they’ve come to a safe place,

an3.36:22.3.eng: They’ve gone beyond all threats and perils,

an3.37:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhamiyaṃ, bhikkhave, pakkhassa catunnaṃ mahārājānaṃ amaccā pārisajjā imaṃ lokaṃ anuvicaranti:
an3.37:1.1.eng: “On the eighth day of the fortnight, mendicants, the ministers and councillors of the four great kings wander about the world, thinking:

an3.37:1.2.pli: ‘kacci bahū manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karontī’ti.
an3.37:1.2.eng: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in their families, observing and keeping vigil on the sabbath, and making merit.’

an3.37:1.3.pli: Cātuddasiṃ, bhikkhave, pakkhassa catunnaṃ mahārājānaṃ puttā imaṃ lokaṃ anuvicaranti:
an3.37:1.3.eng: And on the fourteenth day of the fortnight, the sons of the four great kings wander about the world, thinking:

an3.37:1.4.pli: ‘kacci bahū manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karontī’ti.
an3.37:1.4.eng: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’

an3.37:1.5.pli: Tadahu, bhikkhave, uposathe pannarase cattāro mahārājāno sāmaññeva imaṃ lokaṃ anuvicaranti:
an3.37:1.5.eng: And on the fifteenth day sabbath, the four great kings themselves wander about the world, thinking:

an3.37:1.6.pli: ‘kacci bahū manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karontī’ti.
an3.37:1.6.eng: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’

an3.37:2.1.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, appakā honti manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karonti.
an3.37:2.1.eng: If only a few humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit,

an3.37:2.2.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, cattāro mahārājāno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sudhammāya sabhāya sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ārocenti:
an3.37:2.2.eng: the four great kings address the gods of the thirty-three, seated together in the Hall of Clear Right:

an3.37:2.3.pli: ‘appakā kho, mārisā, manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karontī’ti.
an3.37:2.3.eng: ‘Only a few humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’

an3.37:2.4.pli: Tena kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā anattamanā honti:
an3.37:2.4.eng: Then the gods of the thirty-three are disappointed, thinking,

an3.37:2.5.pli: ‘dibbā vata, bho, kāyā parihāyissanti, paripūrissanti asurakāyā’ti.
an3.37:2.5.eng: ‘The heavenly hosts will dwindle, while the titan hosts will swell!’

an3.37:3.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bahū honti manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karonti.
an3.37:3.1.eng: But if many humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit,

an3.37:3.2.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, cattāro mahārājāno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sudhammāya sabhāya sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ārocenti:
an3.37:3.2.eng: the four great kings address the gods of the thirty-three, seated together in the Hall of Clear Right:

an3.37:3.3.pli: ‘bahū kho, mārisā, manussā manussesu matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino uposathaṃ upavasanti paṭijāgaronti puññāni karontī’ti.
an3.37:3.3.eng: ‘Many humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’

an3.37:3.4.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā attamanā honti:
an3.37:3.4.eng: Then the gods of the thirty-three are pleased, thinking,

an3.37:3.5.pli: ‘dibbā vata bho kāyā paripūrissanti, parihāyissanti asurakāyā’ti.
an3.37:3.5.eng: ‘The heavenly hosts will swell, while the titan hosts will dwindle!’

an3.37:4.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
an3.37:4.1.eng: Once upon a time, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

an3.37:5.4.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

an3.37:5.5.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

an3.37:5.6.eng: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’

an3.37:6.1.pli: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, sakkena devānamindena gāthā duggītā na sugītā dubbhāsitā na subhāsitā.
an3.37:6.1.eng: But that verse was poorly sung by Sakka, lord of gods, not well sung; poorly spoken, not well spoken.

an3.37:6.3.pli: Sakko hi, bhikkhave, devānamindo avītarāgo avītadoso avītamoho.
an3.37:6.3.eng: Sakka, lord of gods, is not free of greed, hate, and delusion.

an3.37:7.1.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā brahmacariyo katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, tassa kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kallaṃ vacanāya:
an3.37:7.1.eng: But for a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—it is appropriate to say:

an3.37:8.4.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

an3.37:8.5.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

an3.37:8.6.eng: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’

an3.37:9.2.pli: So hi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vītarāgo vītadoso vītamoho”ti.
an3.37:9.2.eng: Because that mendicant is free of greed, hate, and delusion.”

an3.38:1.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
an3.38:1.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

an3.38:2.4.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

an3.38:2.5.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

an3.38:2.6.eng: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’

an3.38:3.1.pli: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, sakkena devānamindena gāthā duggītā na sugītā dubbhāsitā na subhāsitā.
an3.38:3.1.eng: But that verse was poorly sung by Sakka, lord of gods, not well sung; poorly spoken, not well spoken.

an3.38:3.3.pli: Sakko hi, bhikkhave, devānamindo aparimutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘aparimutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
an3.38:3.3.eng: Because Sakka, lord of gods, is not exempt from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. He is not exempt from suffering, I say.

an3.38:4.1.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, tassa kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kallaṃ vacanāya:
an3.38:4.1.eng: But for a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—it is appropriate to say:

an3.38:5.4.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

an3.38:5.5.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

an3.38:5.6.eng: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’

an3.38:6.2.pli: So hi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parimutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘parimutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
an3.38:6.2.eng: Because that mendicant is exempt from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. He is exempt from suffering, I say.”

an3.39:1.1.eng: “My lifestyle was delicate, mendicants, most delicate, extremely delicate.

an3.39:1.2.pli: Mama sudaṃ, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane pokkharaṇiyo kāritā honti.
an3.39:1.2.eng: In my father’s home, lotus ponds were made just for me.

an3.39:1.3.pli: Ekattha sudaṃ, bhikkhave, uppalaṃ vappati, ekattha padumaṃ, ekattha puṇḍarīkaṃ, yāvadeva mamatthāya.
an3.39:1.3.eng: In some, blue water lilies blossomed, while in others, there were pink or white lotuses, just for my benefit.

an3.39:1.4.pli: Na kho panassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, akāsikaṃ candanaṃ dhāremi. Kāsikaṃ, bhikkhave, su me taṃ veṭhanaṃ hoti, kāsikā kañcukā, kāsikaṃ nivāsanaṃ, kāsiko uttarāsaṅgo.
an3.39:1.4.eng: I only used sandalwood from Kāsi, and my turbans, jackets, sarongs, and upper robes also came from Kāsi.

an3.39:1.5.pli: Rattindivaṃ kho pana me su taṃ, bhikkhave, setacchattaṃ dhārīyati:
an3.39:1.5.eng: And a white parasol was held over me night and day, with the thought:

an3.39:1.6.pli: ‘mā naṃ phusi sītaṃ vā uṇhaṃ vā tiṇaṃ vā rajo vā ussāvo vā’ti.
an3.39:1.6.eng: ‘Don’t let cold, heat, grass, dust, or damp bother him.’

an3.39:2.1.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, tayo pāsādā ahesuṃ—eko hemantiko, eko gimhiko, eko vassiko.
an3.39:2.1.eng: I had three stilt longhouses—one for the winter, one for the summer, and one for the rainy season.

an3.39:2.2.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, vassike pāsāde vassike cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ orohāmi.
an3.39:2.2.eng: I stayed in a stilt longhouse without coming downstairs for the four months of the rainy season, where I was entertained by musicians—none of them men.

an3.39:2.3.pli: Yathā kho pana, bhikkhave, aññesaṃ nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa kaṇājakaṃ bhojanaṃ dīyati bilaṅgadutiyaṃ, evamevassu me, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa sālimaṃsodano dīyati.
an3.39:2.3.eng: While the bondservants, workers, and staff in other houses are given rough gruel with false black pepper to eat, in my father’s home they are given fine rice with meat.

an3.39:3.1.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, evarūpāya iddhiyā samannāgatassa evarūpena ca sukhumālena etadahosi:
an3.39:3.1.eng: Amid such prosperity and such a delicate lifestyle, I thought:

an3.39:3.2.pli: ‘assutavā kho puthujjano attanā jarādhammo samāno jaraṃ anatīto paraṃ jiṇṇaṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā, ahampi khomhi jarādhammo jaraṃ anatīto.
an3.39:3.2.eng: ‘When an unlearned ordinary person—who is liable to grow old, not being exempt from old age—sees someone else who is old, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

an3.39:3.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhammo samāno jaraṃ anatīto paraṃ jiṇṇaṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
an3.39:3.3.eng: But since I, too, am liable to grow old, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is old.’

an3.39:3.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo yobbane yobbanamado so sabbaso pahīyi.
an3.39:3.4.eng: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of youth.

an3.39:4.1.pli: Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhiṃ anatīto paraṃ byādhitaṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā:
an3.39:4.1.eng: ‘When an unlearned ordinary person—who is liable to get sick, not being exempt from sickness—sees someone else who is sick, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

an3.39:4.2.pli: ‘ahampi khomhi byādhidhammo byādhiṃ anatīto, ahañceva kho pana byādhidhammo samāno byādhiṃ anatīto paraṃ byādhikaṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
an3.39:4.2.eng: But since I, too, am liable to get sick, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is sick.’

an3.39:4.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo ārogye ārogyamado so sabbaso pahīyi.
an3.39:4.3.eng: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of health.

an3.39:5.1.pli: Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇaṃ anatīto paraṃ mataṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā:
an3.39:5.1.eng: ‘When an unlearned ordinary person—who is liable to die, not being exempt from death—sees someone else who is dead, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

an3.39:5.2.pli: ‘ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo, maraṇaṃ anatīto, ahaṃ ceva kho pana maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇaṃ anatīto paraṃ mataṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
an3.39:5.2.eng: But since I, too, am liable to die, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is dead.’

an3.39:5.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo jīvite jīvitamado so sabbaso pahīyīti.
an3.39:5.3.eng: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of life.

an3.39:6.3.eng: The vanity of youth, of health, and of life.

an3.39:6.4.pli: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.39:6.4.eng: Intoxicated with the vanity of youth, an unlearned ordinary person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.39:6.5.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an3.39:6.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an3.39:6.6.eng: Intoxicated with the vanity of health …

an3.39:6.7.pli: jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.39:6.7.eng: Intoxicated with the vanity of life, an unlearned ordinary person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.39:6.8.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an3.39:6.8.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an3.39:7.1.pli: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
an3.39:7.1.eng: Intoxicated with the vanity of youth, health, or life, a mendicant disavows the training and returns to a lesser life.

an3.39:7.3.pli: jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatīti.

an3.39:8.2.eng: and so are old age and death.

an3.39:8.3.eng: Though this is how their nature is,

an3.39:9.1.eng: If I were to be disgusted

an3.39:9.2.eng: with creatures whose nature is such,

an3.39:9.3.eng: it would not be appropriate for me,

an3.39:9.4.eng: since my life is just the same.

an3.39:10.2.eng: I understood the truth without attachments.

an3.39:12.4.eng: I’m committed to the spiritual life.”

an3.4:1.1.eng: “A fool is known by three things.

an3.4:1.3.pli: Accayaṃ accayato na passati, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ nappaṭikaroti, parassa kho pana accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhāti.
an3.4:1.3.eng: They don’t recognize when they’ve made a mistake. When they do recognize it they don’t deal with it properly. And when someone else confesses a mistake to them, they don’t accept it properly.

an3.4:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo veditabbo.
an3.4:1.4.eng: These are the three things by which a fool is known.

an3.4:2.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo.
an3.4:2.1.eng: An astute person is known by three things.

an3.4:2.3.pli: Accayaṃ accayato passati, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti, parassa kho pana accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ paṭiggaṇhāti.
an3.4:2.3.eng: They recognize when they’ve made a mistake. When they recognize it they deal with it properly. And when someone else confesses a mistake to them, they accept it properly.

an3.4:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo.
an3.4:2.4.eng: These are the three things by which an astute person is known.
